title: 106_hr975
content: Reduction in volume of steel imports. The President must reduce steel imports to not exceed the average volume imported in the 36-month period before July 1997. The Secretary of the Treasury and the Secretary of Commerce will enforce import restraints through the Customs Service. The President must restrict steel imports to the average volume imported in the 36-month period before July 1997. The Customs Service will refuse entry of steel products exceeding allowable import levels, including various categories such as semifinished, plates, sheets, wire rods, and pipes. This restriction will expire after 3 years from the enactment of the Act. SEC. 2. STEEL IMPORT NOTIFICATION AND MONITORING PROGRAM. The Secretary of Commerce, in consultation with the Secretary of the Treasury, must establish a steel import notification and monitoring program within 30 days of the Act's enactment. Importers of products classified under chapter 72 or 73 of the Harmonized Tariff Schedule must obtain a steel import notification certificate before entering the United States. To obtain the certificate, importers must submit an application with their information, supplier's information, and producer's information. The import notification requirements include the producer's name and address, country of origin, country of import, Customs port of entry, expected entry date, goods description and classification, quantity, CIF and FAS values, and purpose of entry. The import notification requirements for steel include details such as producer information, country of origin, entry details, and purpose of entry. A steel import notification certificate is necessary for merchandise classified under certain chapters before entering the customs territory of the United States. The Secretary of Commerce issues steel import notification certificates valid for 30 days. Statistical information on steel imports, including classification, country of origin, and entry details, is compiled and published weekly. The Secretary of Commerce issues steel import notification certificates valid for 30 days, including details like classification, country of origin, port of entry, quantity, and value. The information is compiled and made publicly available weekly. Fees may be charged for issuing certificates, and single producer and exporter countries are subject to public disclosure by the Secretary of Commerce. The Secretary of Commerce will release information on imports from single producer/exporter countries, and may create regulations for the steel import notification program. The House of Representatives passed the document on March 17, 1999, with Jeff Trandahl as the Clerk.
